text: NARRATOR: April, 2016--

NASA's pioneering
New Horizons probe

reaches the Kuiper Belt, a
dark distant region of space
at the edge of our solar system.

As the New Horizons probe moves
beyond its first target, Pluto,

its sensors capture
a large object
on a mysterious trajectory.

Scientists give it
an ominous name--
Arawn.

Arawn is named
after the Celtic god
of death, war, terror, revenge.

Not a pleasant person,
as you can well imagine.

NARRATOR: Whatever Arawn
is, it's behaving strangely.

It seems illuminated,
but then it goes dark.

It lights up and darkens
in a precise rhythm.

Scientists realize that
this object is rotating.

If it's spinning once
every 5 and 1/2 hours,

that means the front edge
is like 50 miles an hour.

So that's like
something the size

of the state of Delaware
completing a full spin
in about a quarter of a day.

NARRATOR: Scientists
expect the Kuiper

Belt to be filled with
objects made of rock and ice.

But Arawn's spin suggests it
is made of something else.

Arawn is spinning so fast
that the centrifugal force
could actually tear it apart.

Is it made of something
stronger than rock and ice?

NARRATOR: New Horizons
moves in so its sensors
can get a closer look.

Whatever Arawn is,
we're about to find out.

But at the crucial moment,
the probe circuits suddenly,
inexplicably, go dead.

All of a sudden,
transmission was cut off.

This suggests that someone is
monitoring our very presence.

When you're a
mission operator,

it's really one of the last
things that you want to see.

You're very concerned that there
could be something seriously
wrong with your spacecraft.

And it's jeopardizing
the mission.

It does beg the question,
is someone or something
trying to jam NASA's signal?

NARRATOR: Before
contact is lost,

scientists see that
Arawn is spinning

in a manner consistent
with a large spaceship.

It's spinning as fast
as it is, as though it's
creating artificial gravity.

NARRATOR: Spinning creates an
artificial gravity environment

within the hollow
center of the object,

like an inverted planet with
the surface on the inside
rather than the outside.

NASA recognizes
that long-haul space

travel will only
be possible if we
can somehow replicate gravity.

This is not only good to keep
you healthy because our bodies

used to gravity,
but also it's just

much easier to get
things done if you're
not floating around the room.

NARRATOR: Analysts
compare the mystery object

called Arawn with
NASA's attempts
at recreating gravity in space.

These two were based on the
concept of a spinning ship.

Engineers, scientists
looked at concepts

for artificial gravity,
gigantic structures in space

spinning around, where on the
outer edges you had forests,

you had cities, you had places
where people could live.

NARRATOR: In the 1960s, NASA
begins ground based experiments

on artificial gravity,
building a huge research
facility at Langley.

Its centerpiece is a Space
Station-scale spinning rig
designed for human guinea pigs.

They would suspend a
test subject sideways,

spin the wheel-- it's
about 40 foot in diameter--

have them stand on
the inner parts there.

And as it went, nine revolutions
a minute was about half
of Earth's gravity.

That must have been
the weirdest experience.

It's like a fairground
ride on steroids.
I would never get on this thing.

NARRATOR: Neither NASA
nor any other space agency

is anywhere near building
a spinning spacecraft
on the scale of Arawn.

What's more, whatever kind of
creature might be inside Arawn,

it's unlikely that
they're anything like us.

Neuropsychologist Dr. Jana
Kaplan from Brandeis University

has been studying the effects
of artificial gravity on humans.
So the room is stationary.

We're just about
to start spinning.
Alberto, you can start.
OK, Jana.
We are starting out.
Going up to speed.

So the room will
accelerate to 10

RPM, which is one complete
revolution every six seconds.

NARRATOR: Kaplan's
work has highlighted

the immense difficulties
of creating and surviving
artificial gravity.
Even walking is hard.

When you make a step, your
leg is subject to Coriolis force
deviation.

NARRATOR: The Coriolis
force is a bizarre effect

that only happens in
rotating environments.

It causes straight
line motions to bend.

And it's not the
only problem humans
would face in a spinning craft.
We experience motion sickness.
There's confusion.

The person is, for all practical
purposes, dysfunctional.

I would estimate we maybe
have 10 more minutes.
I feel kind of a cold sweat.

I can see the progression
of the symptoms.

The sweat is now
over my whole body.

There's a fine line
between how much spitting
the human body can tolerate.

You start speaking too fast,
you could start blowing chunks.

NARRATOR: In space,
that can be disastrous.

It'll spread around
and contaminate the air

that you breathe, and
can cause short circuits
in your electronics.
It can be extremely dangerous.

NARRATOR: Humans
are some way off
mastering artificial gravity.

And indeed, although
Arawn's 50 mile an hour

surface speed is fast
enough to create gravity,

it's not enough gravity
for human passengers.

If Arawn is some kind of
craft, it's manned by beings
who are nothing like us.

The question is, what
are they doing there?

If Arawn is a spacecraft,
why is it spinning so slowly?

It could it be that what is
living on it is not humanlike.

It could it be that
what's on it is

not a creature that needs
artificial gravity the way
that we do.

NARRATOR: Alien
beings able to operate

in a gravity environment
as low as this would
look very different to us.

It will be a very different
body, more like a blob
with some tentacles.

So you can have something
like your vital organs,

the brain-- everything's
kind of centrally located.

And then just squid
tentacles, like,
a-- almost like a sea urchin.

NARRATOR: And
there's good reason

for Arawnites to skulk
in the Kuiper Belt,
far from the nearest planet.

Given that there are
trillions of objects

out there in the Kuiper Belt
and they're too far away and too

dark for us to really see, if
you were an alien that wanted

to set up an observation post
to study these funky creatures

called humans on Earth, that
would be a pretty good place
to set it up.

If you're a zero
gravity life form,

you want to skirt
very cautiously
around the planetary zone.

Suddenly, places like
Earth have become a danger
zone, a veritable black hole.

If they tried to walk
around on Eath's surface,
they would just get mushed.

It would not be a
good place for them.

NARRATOR: As the New Horizons
probe moves away from Arawn,

it's spookily
flickers back to life.

Whatever happened to
New Horizons' computers,

it prevented NASA
from finding out

the truth about the
intriguing spinning object.

The origin and nature of
Arawn remains a mystery.

We don't have any new missions
planned to the Kuiper Belt
at this time.

It could be that we
are in the dark on what
Arawn is for a very long time.
[STATIC NOISES]
